title: A splash of colour: Hamilton picks art for 37 downtown utility boxes | CBC News
text:
Who says a utility box can't be beautiful?

Hamilton will be a bit more colourful this fall, with work from dozens of artists featured on utility boxes around downtown.

The city asked for public feedback on designs earlier this summer and says around 1,900 people weighed in with their opinion.

The successful artists were announced by the city on Tuesday.

Some of the 38 shortlisted designs for downtown utility boxes. (Submitted by City of Hamilton)

Local artist Charlit Floriano will decorate a handful of larger electrical boxes downtown; her series "Hamilton Enchanted" corresponds with five specific locations.

Another 31 artists will showcase their designs on 32 smaller traffic signal boxes.

The city plans to wrap several utility boxes like this one in artistic designs, primarily to combat graffiti. (Laura Howells/CBC)

Art will be on boxes by fall

The art, printed on graffiti-resistant wraps, will be in place by fall and remain for the next five to 10 years.

Preventing graffiti is a major goal of the public art project, said Ken Coit, the city's public art program manager, earlier this summer.

One of Hamilton artist's Charlit Floriano designs, which will be featured on an electrical box in downtown Hamilton this fall. (Charlit Floriano)

The 32 traffic box designs were based off 1,745 people voting on 38 finalists.

Meanwhile, a volunteer jury decided on the artist for the five electrical boxes through a more "traditional" public art selection process, said Coit.

The five-person jury made its selection based on about 200 comments from the public, along with artistic excellence, "ability to deter graffiti" and other factors, the city says.

Charlit Floriano is a local Hamilton artist who designed this wrap for an electrical box as part of a five-box series. (Charlit Floriano)

The featured artists will receive $650 for their design, while Floriano will earn $4,000 for her five-box series.

The project is funded by developers, through the downtown Hamilton public art reserve.

The city hopes the artwork will add vibrancy and interest to the downtown core, said Coit.

"It's great to be able to have all these artists showcase their work," he added.
description: The new public art will be in place by fall.
